title: Help Is Sought for Migrants Dying at Sea
body:
Photo

GENEVA — Record numbers of people from the Middle East and Africa are putting their lives in the hands of smugglers to get across the Mediterranean to Europe, and record numbers are dying in the effort, the United Nations refugee agency said on Tuesday in calling for urgent and concerted action by European governments.

More than 300 asylum seekers and migrants died over the weekend when three boats capsized or sank, Melissa Fleming, a spokeswoman for the refugee agency, told reporters in Geneva. In the worst episode, only 19 survivors were rescued from a boat carrying at least 270 people that overturned Friday off the Libyan coast east of Tripoli.

“There were bodies floating everywhere,” she said, citing Libyan Coast Guard members who said they had found five children and seven women among the victims. Survivors said that the human traffickers running the operation had been pushing more and more people onto the packed vessel minutes before it departed, Ms. Fleming said.

The Italian Navy said it had saved about 4,000 migrants and asylum seekers over the weekend. More than 50 drowned, Ms. Fleming said.

With these deaths, at least 1,600 people have died since June trying to cross from North Africa to Europe, Ms. Fleming said, compared with more than 600 deaths in all of 2013. She thanked the Italian Navy for having averted even more deaths.
